ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was my favorite course of the semester. The field trips were not only incredibly fun, but so much work went into designing full, informative days, making it a valuable learning experience. The course was incredibly informative, both for someone wanting introductory overview, and for depth of content. If I would change anything: The days with long lists of plants and uses were a bit challenging for my attention span. but still really useful and interesting information. The budget exercises were great and it would have been fun to do more interactive projects like that. It would be really cool to do a nutrient budget, like the one from las Canadas, too. Again,the field trips were spectacular, but I would have liked to be a bit more hands on at times. Thanks so much for a wonderful course. It is super valuable to the school, and really hope it's taught every year.
This is the best course i've taken at FES. Eric is the best lecturer i've had at FES and his command over subject matter and current events within agroforestry was amazing.
Eric is a really great, dedicated and knowledgable teacher. I learned so much and felt that he was always available to talk through things and give additional perspectives.
I was auditing and did therefore not attend field trips or do the readings, so I didn't answer these questions.

incredible course with lots of technical and practical knowledge for those with agriculture interests. Eric is a wonderful professor and has a wealth of knowledge. FES would be very advantaged by continuing to offer this course with Eric as the professor.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This course provided a great overview of perennial agriculture's potential, as well as the challenges to adopting it on a broad scale. It is an important topic that is not covered at all in other course offerings.
answered in question 13
The trip to Mexico. It was incredible. Very well organized and incredibly powerful for learning.
Field trips! So essential to understanding theoretical issues in practice.
Eric's lectures and the field trips to New York and Mexico together provided an incredible, well-rounded learning opportunity.
My classmates presentations and Eric transmitting his knowledge and experience to us.

Despite being a 3-hour class from 6-9 in the evenings, Eric kept lectures very engaging with his passion about the course content, and interactive in-class activities. The New York and Mexico field trips were phenomenal opportunities for students to learn more about agroforestry in person, easily among the top highlights of my time here at F&ES.
Eric is really fun and super passionate about this. And he ties in so many different topics. Very enjoyable.
Eric Field Trips

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: answered in question 13
Perhaps more variation in use of class time, perhaps other outside speakers.
Reading response each week is a little excessive and I don't think it helped my learning.

The demand for this course is much higher than the 12 student cap, so if there is any way to expand the course in the future, while still providing a field trip component, more students could benefit.
I would have liked to do more practical agricultural work during this course, and focused more in agroforestry farming planing.
The weekly responses are fine but I wonder if they could be made more meaningful/interactive, as right now students are not sure if they are being read or just checked off.
Perhaps it would be good to do a bit more about absolute foundations (think silvicultural aspects when mixing plants) of agroforestry.
Eric can improve his lecturing style slightly. Some lectures were repetitive of the readings. I would have preferred to use the readings as prep for learning new material from the lecture

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: yes. the field trips were well timed and related to lecture material
We did not have a discussion section.
see above

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provided a great practical understanding of perennial agriculture with the chance to see these systems in practice. While there are some agricultural policy courses at FES, this is one of the only ones to actually examine agricultural practices.

It was new subject matter to me but it was taught very well. It opened my eyes to sustainable agriculture (my background is in clean energy) and has motivated me to consider a career in agriculture and agroforestry.
This class changed my life. I not only discovered what it is I want to do, I made great connections along the way and witnessed sites that will influence my future decisions on the job.
The course complements my experience in the land use sector which has largely been focused on policy and finance so far, with a stronger command of actual agricultural systems
As a Master of Forestry I also wanted to know about Agroforestry options that are often important in developing countries.
Although I am not an MF, I take a lot of MF courses because I want practical land management skills. This course should be included in the MF coursework.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course to learn more about perennial agriculture, especially the potential for perennial agriculture in temperate areas.
My focus here is agroforestry. This is the ONLY course offering material on both the ecological and social side of managing sustainable agriculture. SO glad I took it, but there need to be more!
To learn about sustainable agriculture and agroforestry.
I took a permaculture design course this summer and wanted to get a deeper understanding of the science and different applications of plant polycultures around the world.
Personal interests and experience in tropical agriculture in Ecuador.
See Question 17. Also, agroforestry is just cool.
because it is one of the only practical agriculture offerings.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, this class provided a good understanding of perennial agriculture in both temperate and tropical areas, and the potential for carbon sequestration through these systems.
yes.
My learning and the value of the course exceeded my expectations.
Yes, my expectations were met and exceeded. I hope this course is offered for many years to come.
Surpassed
Like I said, a bit more detail on the "how to build" an agroforestry plot would have been good.
yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: These exercises gave us a great opportunity to put lecture material into practice. they were fun and informative and everyone participated and gave insights from their own backgrounds. I t was a great chance for us to learn from each other.
Knowing my classmates and their interests, working successfully in teams, applying knowledge from the class to possible farm projects.
Was great but sometimes difficult to tie me in as an Auditor.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the course -- it's a great topic and Eric is an expert in perennial agriculture.
Take it!!! Read the readings. They are super interesting. Ask lots of questions, and chat with Eric all the time, because he has a breadth of great knowledge .
Simply to take it. It's a great course and they won't regret it.

Take this course! Eric is an encyclopedia of information on carbon farming and agroforestry. The lectures and field trips are fascinating if you are interested in food/agroecology. I so enjoyed getting to know my classmates better on our field trip excursions to New York and Mexico. The class is currently capped at about 12, but even if you shop it and don't get in the first time, Eric is welcoming to auditors and independent study projects.
Take advantage as much as you cam from Eric's experience in Agroforestry.
Absolutely take it, could be the best course you take at F&ES.
If you audit you can't participate in the field trips.
definitely take it
